perturbation.original_text: "Base Salary" means the Employee's total base salary as of each January 1st exclusive of special payments such as bonuses or commissions, but including any salary reductions made in accordance with Section 125 or 401(k) of the Code.
perturbation.changed_text: "Base Salary" means the Employee's total salary as determined by the Employer.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of 'Base Salary' provides a specific calculation method. The modified definition is ambiguous, leaving the determination of the base salary solely to the Employer's discretion. This contradicts Article IV which uses 'Base Salary' to determine the death benefit, creating uncertainty in the benefit calculation.

perturbation.original_text: Upon the death of the Employee while this Agreement is in force, the Employee's beneficiary as named in the Beneficiary Designation Form on page 6 (or as it may be amended according to the terms set forth on page 6) for this Agreement will be entitled to receive from the Policy proceeds an amount equal to the lesser of: (a) (two (2) times the Employee's annualized base salary at the time of death as provided by the Employer's payroll department) plus $100,000, reduced by any amount payable under the Employer's group term life insurance plan, or (b) the Net Amount At Risk. The Employer shall be the beneficiary of the remaining death proceeds of the policy after the Employee's interest is determined. Within 60 days after the death of the Employee, the Employer will provide to the "Insurer" a written statement indicating the amount of each policy's proceeds the Employee's beneficiary is entitled to receive.
perturbation.changed_text: Upon the death of the Employee while this Agreement is in force, the Employee's beneficiary as named in the Beneficiary Designation Form on page 6 (or as it may be amended according to the terms set forth on page 6) for this Agreement will be entitled to receive from the Policy proceeds an amount to be determined by the Employer at the time of death. The Employer shall be the beneficiary of the remaining death proceeds of the policy after the Employee's interest is determined. Within 60 days after the death of the Employee, the Employer will provide to the "Insurer" a written statement indicating the amount of each policy's proceeds the Employee's beneficiary is entitled to receive.
perturbation.explanation: The original Article IV defines exactly how the beneficiary proceeds will be paid out, namely 'the lesser of (a) (two (2) times the Employee's annualized base salary at the time of death as provided by the Employer's payroll department) plus $100,000, reduced by any amount payable under the Employer's group term life insurance plan, or (b) the Net Amount At Risk'. The changed text removes this definition of proceeds and instead gives the Employer discretion to determine that amount at the time of death. This creates an internal contradiction in the purpose of the agreement. This also creates uncertainty in enforcement.

perturbation.original_text: The Employer will keep possession of the Policies. The Employer agrees from time to time to make the policies available to the Employee or to the "Insurer" for the purpose of endorsing or filing any change of beneficiary on the Policies but the Policies will promptly be returned to the Employer.
perturbation.changed_text: The Employer will keep possession of the Policies.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause specifies that the Employer must make the policies available for beneficiary changes. By removing this, the Employee's right to change the beneficiary is impaired, contradicting the 'Split Dollar Policy Endorsement Beneficiary Designation' section on page 6, which grants the Employee the right to change the beneficiary. This creates uncertainty regarding the Employee's rights and makes the agreement ambiguous to enforce.
